name: OpenHPC
description: OpenHPC is a collaborative, community effort that initiated from a desire to aggregate a number of common ingredients required to deploy and manage High Performance Computing (HPC) Linux clusters including provisioning tools, resource management, I/O clients, development tools, and a variety of scientific libraries. Packages provided by OpenHPC have been pre-built with HPC integration in mind with a goal to provide re-usable building blocks for the HPC community. Over time, the community also plans to identify and develop abstraction interfaces between key components to further enhance modularity and interchangeability. The community includes representation from a variety of sources including software vendors, equipment manufacturers, research institutions, supercomputing sites, and others.

name: Coccinelle
description: A program matching and transformation tool for C code.
description_good_justification:
https://coccinelle.gitlabpages.inria.fr/website/

What is Coccinelle?
Coccinelle is a program matching and transformation engine which provides the language SmPL (Semantic Patch Language) for specifying desired matches and transformations in C code. Coccinelle was initially targeted towards performing collateral evolutions in Linux. Such evolutions comprise the changes that are needed in client code in response to evolutions in library APIs, and may include modifications such as renaming a function, adding a function argument whose value is somehow context-dependent, and reorganizing a data structure. Beyond collateral evolutions, Coccinelle is successfully used (by us and others) for finding and fixing bugs in systems code.
interact_justification:
https://coccinelle.gitlabpages.inria.fr/website/contact.html

Contact
Any questions about Coccinelle may be directed to cocci@systeme.lip6.fr. The mailing list is moderated for non-members. If you would like to join the mailing list, send an empty e-mail to cocci-subscribe@systeme.lip6.fr. You can also manage your subscription or see the archives at https://systeme.lip6.fr/mailman/listinfo/cocci.
contribution_justification:
https://gitlab.inria.fr/coccinelle/coccinelle and https://github.com/coccinelle/coccinelle
The contribution instructions are in the source code available in the gitlab page and mirrored on github.
contribution_requirements_justification:
ehttps://gitlab.inria.fr/coccinelle/coccinelle and https://github.com/coccinelle/coccinelle
There is no particular coding standard.  But contributors are required to sign the developers certificate of origin.
license_location_justification:
The source repository includes the GPLv2 in a file called license.txt.
https://gitlab.inria.fr/coccinelle/coccinelle/-/blob/master/license.txt
floss_license_justification: Coccinelle is the only software produced by the project, and Coccinelle is GPLv2 (the question doesn't really seem appropriate to our context).
floss_license_osi_justification: I'm not sure what this means.  See the previous answer.
documentation_basics_justification: https://coccinelle.gitlabpages.inria.fr/website/documentation.html
documentation_interface_justification: Coccinelle is a command line tool.  The documentation does include a list of the command line arguments: https://coccinelle.gitlabpages.inria.fr/website/docs/options.pdf
repo_public_justification:
We expect users to look at https://github.com/coccinelle/coccinelle
Our internal repository is also publicly readable: https://gitlab.inria.fr/coccinelle/coccinelle
repo_track_justification: Git provides these features.
repo_interim_justification: Both the gitlab repository and the github mirror contain all commits.
repo_distributed_justification: We use git.
report_tracker_justification: Gitlab issue tracker mostly for internal use, Github issue tracker mostly for external use.
report_process_justification: We accept contributions via our mailing list or if necessary via github.  As almost all of our code is written in OCaml, which is not well known to our user community, we do not receive or expect many contributions.
report_responses_justification: We receive a huge number of complaints from one user that are mostly noise and outside of our priorities.  We sometimes respond to them, but most conversations end up inconclusively.   Issues form all other users we try to address in a timely manner.
enhancement_responses_justification: We responds to bug reports and enhancement requests following the same strategy.
report_archive_justification: Reports and responses are either in the mailing list which has public archives or in the gitlab/github issue trackers.  https://lore.kernel.org/cocci/
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: It's not clear what kind of vulnerabilities would be relevant to our application area (program transformation).
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No reports received in the last 10 years.
test_invocation_justification: I'm not sure OCaml has a standard way to invoke a test suite.  In any case, our test suite has an ad hoc interface.
test_most_justification: We have over 600 tests, but it's not likely that all branches are covered.
test_policy_justification: The policy is informal, but the developers all agree that this is a good policy and try to satisfy it whenever possible.
tests_are_added_justification: Around 30 commits have been added to the tests directory since January 2020.
warnings_fixed_justification: We prefer that there are no warnings at all, and ensure that there are none in releases.  However, the CI does not enforce this.
warnings_strict_justification: This is trivially met as note in the two points above.  The OCaml compiler doesn't have options for different levels of warnings, as far as I know.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: We build on the functionalities available in gitlab.  The CI builds and runs tests on various Linux distributions
discussion_justification: Mailman mailing list, archived on lore.
english_justification: The entire website is in English.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

vulnerability_report_process_justificati: GitHub's Issue tracker is available for this: https://github.com/sjvrijn/mf2/issues, although no vulnerabilities are expected due to the nature of this software.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: No vulnerabilities are expected in the first place, there is no private information involved in this project.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No vulnerabilities are expected in the first place, there is no private information involved in this project.
build_justification: No building necessarily required, PyPI distribution builds are done using the default tool 'twine'
build_common_tools_justification: The software is written in Python, can be used as-is or installed using the common tool 'pip'
build_floss_tools_justification: Python, pip and any other python package requirements are FLOSS tools (as far as I'm aware)
test_justification: The Travis CI service is used to run the tests using pytest in tests/ directory (https://travis-ci.com/github/sjvrijn/mf2), as shown by a badge in the README
test_invocation_justification: Common tool pytest is used, which means that `pytest` or `pytest tests` invokes all included tests, as described in https://github.com/sjvrijn/mf2/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
test_most_justification: The project currently has 100% coverage using the property tests, as tracked by Coveralls: https://coveralls.io/github/sjvrijn/mf2, and shown by a badge in the README
test_policy_justification: The process as mentioned in CONTRIBUTING.md explicitly mentions this, and it is enforced by the automated Coveralls check, which will report any drop in test coverage.
tests_are_added_justification: Test coverage history, git history and changelog.txt (https://github.com/sjvrijn/mf2/blob/master/changelog.txt) are available, showing that any major changes have had had corresponding tests added.
tests_documented_added_justification: The process as mentioned in CONTRIBUTING.md explicitly mentions this, and it is enforced by the automated Coveralls check, which will report any drop in test coverage.
warnings_justification: Code quality is checked Codacy CI system using https://app.codacy.com/manual/sjvrijn/mf2/dashboard
warnings_fixed_justification: -Werror flag is enabled in the CI tests
warnings_strict_justification: -Werror flag is enabled in the CI tests
know_secure_design_justification: The main developer is aware that by keeping the scope of this project as limited as it is, no security issues/vulnerabilities can arise
know_common_errors_justification: The main developer is aware that by keeping the scope of this project as limited as it is, no security issues/vulnerabilities can arise
crypto_password_storage_justification: No secure information, such as usernames or passwords, are processed or stored
delivery_mitm_justification: Code can be cloned using SSH/HTTPS from GitHub, PyPI and Conda distributions are accessible by HTTPS
delivery_unsigned_justification: Code can be cloned using SSH/HTTPS from GitHub, PyPI and Conda distributions are accessible by HTTPS
static_analysis_justification: Code is checked using Codacy https://www.codacy.com/manual/sjvrijn/mf2
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Code quality is monitored by https://www.codacy.com/manual/sjvrijn/mf2
static_analysis_often_justification: Codacy checks (https://www.codacy.com/manual/sjvrijn/mf2) are run for every commit/PR that updates the main branch
dynamic_analysis_justification: Test coverage is at 100%, and tests are written using the 'hypothesis' property-based testing tool whenever possible.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: All code is written in Python, i.e. memory-safe
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Some obvious checks for invalid/nonsense inputs are in place, all other potential places for such assertions are more likely in the numpy library that mf2 depends on.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: The Travis CI service is used to run the tests using pytest in tests/ directory (https://travis-ci.com/github/sjvrijn/mf2), as shown by a badge in the README
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: README, code, Documentation on ReadTheDocs and all other information on GitHub such as issue templates is in English.
hardened_site_justification: Repository is hosted on GitHub https://github.com/sjvrijn/mf2 // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: Package can be installed using Python's default tool 'pip'
documentation_quick_start_justification: Simple example available in README: https://github.com/sjvrijn/mf2/blob/master/README.md, and more extensive 'Getting Started' page available in the documentation: https://mf2.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting-started.html
documentation_current_justification: API documentation is auto-generated from the source code, and PRs require docstrings for new functions, to be auto-generated into documentation.
documentation_achievements_justification: Badge added in README, which is displayed on Github repository main page: https://github.com/sjvrijn/mf2 (https://github.com/sjvrijn/mf2/blob/master/README.md)
internationalization_justification: The only 'text' that is involved in the use of this project are names of the benchmark functions, which are language independent.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: No vulnerabilities resolved in the past 12 months
build_standard_variables_justification: No native binaries are being generated
build_preserve_debug_justification: Project is written in Python, which does not require a build or installation system.
build_repeatable_justification: Project is written in Python, which does not require a compilation step
installation_development_quick_justifica: Package + development requirements are installable through the documented 'pip install mf2[dev]' flag
automated_integration_testing_justificat: Performed automatically on Github using TravisCI intergration https://travis-ci.com/sjvrijn/mf2
test_statement_coverage80_justification: Statement and branch coverage are at 100%, monitored by Coveralls.io: https://coveralls.io/github/sjvrijn/mf2?branch=master
test_policy_mandated_justification: Requirement is listed in https://github.com/sjvrijn/mf2/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md, and in the https://github.com/sjvrijn/mf2/blob/master/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md

name: MetabolicAtlas
description: Metabolic Atlas web app
sites_https_justification: The website enforces the use of HTTPS.
description_good_justification: There is a one-line description on the website homepage (https://metabolicatlas.org). In addition, more information about the project is described under the About and Documentation pages.
interact_justification: There is a email address advertised in multiple places on the website (contact@metabolicatlas.org). Moreover, there is a button to "Report an issue", describing different ways of getting in touch with the model developers (eg https://metabolicatlas.org/explore/Human-GEM/gem-browser/reaction/HMR_1240).
contribution_justification:
All the source code and data required to deploy Metabolic Atlas are stored in git repositories under the GitHub organisation https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/.
Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/blob/master/LICENSE.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Basic documentation is provided by the Readme at https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/#readme .
documentation_interface_justification:
All the input files required to set up the Metabolic Atlas website are stored in the public repository called `data-files`, under the same GitHub organisation.
The API provided by the website is documented with Swagger at https://metabolicatlas.org/api/v2/ .
repo_public_justification: The project is version-controlled through several repositories on GitHub.
repo_track_justification: Metabolic Atlas relies on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made. Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Final releases, https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/releases, and the commits made during the development process in between each release, https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/commits/develop, are public and easily accessible.
repo_distributed_justification: Metabolic Atlas relies on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed. Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: Final releases are versioned with MAJOR.MINOR, see https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/tags, and the commits made during the development process in between each release have a commit ID, see https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/commits/develop.
version_semver_justification: Semantic versioning is used for releases, see https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/releases, although only MAJOR.MINOR is used and not MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH. The project is quite small and thus using .PATCH does not currently add any value to the versioning.
version_tags_justification: Each release is identified using git tags, see https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/tags for how this works.
release_notes_justification: Each release has hand written release notes that summarize the release, see https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/releases.
release_notes_vulns_justification: Users cannot update the software themselves since the software provided is metabolicatlas.org (a website).
report_tracker_justification: This functionality is provided by GitHub, see https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/issues.
report_responses_justification: The backlog of issues are reviewed in each monthly sprint planning and acknowledged and/or acted upon.
enhancement_responses_justification: The backlog of issues are reviewed in each monthly sprint planning and acknowledged and/or acted upon.
report_archive_justification: The project primarily uses Issues, which are publicly available and searchable https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/issues?q=is%3Aissue+
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: The user can either create a bug report or send an email about potential vulnerabilities to an email address provided in both the project README: https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/blob/develop/README.md and the Contact page of the web site https://metabolicatlas.org/about/contact.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: The user can report potential private vulnerabilities to an email address provided on the Contact page of the web site https://metabolicatlas.org/about/contact.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: 31/3 an issue was created by a researcher in Jira, the previous system for sprint planning and issues. The issue stated concerns regarding possible security issues on the Swagger API that could make Cypher injections possible. The issue was responded to 16/4 and was fixed with the PR https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/pull/557. The response time was 16 days, not 14.
build_justification: The stack is automatically built using Docker by following the instructions in the README.md https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas#readme.
build_floss_tools_justification: The project builds using Docker CE, which by and large can be considered FLOSS.
test_justification: There is a series of tests for API data validation that can be found here: https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/tree/develop/api/test.
test_invocation_justification: The project uses standard CLI commands provided by Jest, one of the most popular testing tools for JavaScript, to run the tests. A single command `yarn test` (`jest`), or more specifically `ma-exec api yarn test` for the standard docker based setup, runs all of the tests.
warnings_justification: The project uses linter tools, see https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/blob/develop/frontend/.eslintrc.js and https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/blob/develop/api/.eslintrc.js,
know_secure_design_justification:
Several of the developers have understanding of the listed design principles. They have undergone computer security related education during university studies and one wrote her master thesis with focus on configuration related web server vulnerabilities.

It is also worth mentioning that the software provided by the project is a read only website and nothing is stored. The only possibility to edit is through code and you have to be maintainer of the project to approve/merge changes.
crypto_pfs_justification: The Nginx webserver is configured for forward secrecy.
static_analysis_justification: CodeQL is used via GitHub Actions for every pull request.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: We are not running dynamic code analysis and thus have not found any vulnerabilities in this way.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions under Issues, Discussions and in Pull Requests.
english_justification: The language of the website and all associated materials and code (GitHub) is English.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
implementation_languages: Vue, Python, JavaScript, Cypher, Shell, Dockerfile
maintained_justification: The project is under active development, with the updates of the past month being visible here https://github.com/MetabolicAtlas/MetabolicAtlas/pulse/monthly .
